conclusion: We have a velocity-time graph for a skydiver who jumps from a helicopter and need to determine the direction of the acceleration during the first 10 seconds.
The graph shows velocity in meters per second (m/s) on the y-axis and time in seconds (s) on the x-axis.
At 10 seconds, the velocity is 20 m/s, and at 15 seconds, it's down to 10 m/s.
The slope of the velocity-time graph at any point gives the acceleration at that instant.

premise: The slope of the graph gives the acceleration.
conclusion: If the velocity is increasing, the slope is positive, meaning positive acceleration. If the velocity is decreasing, the slope is negative, indicating negative acceleration.
From time 0 to about 10 seconds, the velocity is increasing from 0 m/s up to 20 m/s.
The curve is concave up, meaning the rate of increase in velocity is decreasing over time.
After 10 seconds, the velocity starts to decrease from 20 m/s down to about 10 m/s by 15 seconds, and then it levels off at around 10 m/s.

premise: From time 0 to about 10 seconds, the velocity is increasing.
conclusion: Since the velocity is increasing, the acceleration must be in the same direction as the velocity.
In physics, we usually take downward as negative and upward as positive for vertical motion.

premise: The skydiver is moving downward, which is typically considered the negative direction.
conclusion: If his velocity is increasing in the downward direction, that means his acceleration is also negative, which would be in the downward direction.

premise: Acceleration is the change in velocity over time.
conclusion: If velocity is negative and increasing in magnitude (getting more negative), then acceleration is negative, meaning downward.
Initially, when the skydiver jumps, the only force acting on him is gravity, which is downward, providing a constant downward acceleration of approximately 9.8 m/sÂ².

premise: Gravity provides a constant downward acceleration.
conclusion: As the skydiver falls, air resistance starts to build up, which acts upward, opposing his downward motion.
In the early stages of the jump, gravity causes the skydiver to accelerate downward.

premise: As speed increases, air resistance increases.
conclusion: This leads to a reduction in the net downward acceleration.
